Training 

Skinner Plant employees presently involved in operating or maintaining the chlorine process are trained in an overview of the process and detailed applicable operating and maintenance procedures. Skinner Plant ensures that each employee newly assigned to the process is trained and tested to be competent in the operating procedures listed pertaining to their duties.  The Skinner Plant training program includes four elements: (1) initial training and awareness training, (2) refresher training, (3) documentation, and (4) testing.  Each employee presently involved in operating the chlorine process has been trained to receive the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the duties and responsibilities, including chlorine emergency response, as provided in the operating procedures.  

Refresher training is provided every three years or less to each employee operating the covered process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  In addition, the Skinner Plant management ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures prior to startup of a process after a major change as indicated in the Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review procedures.  

Skinner Plant management prepares and retains records of initial and refresher training, which includes the identity of the employee, the date of training, and the signature of the person(s) administering the training.

Contractors

Metropolitan has procedures and policies in place that ensure that the contractors are properly informed of the hazards, have access limitations to these process areas, are familiar with Skinner’s emergency response procedures, and are prepared to safely complete the work. Five-year Accident History Summary

There have been no accidental releases from a covered process at the Skinner Plant within the past five-years that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. 

Emergency Response Program Summary

Skinner Plant is a non-responding facility and, as such, does not have an emergency response plan.  Skinner Plant has Operational Level HAZWOPER-trained plant employees who can handle incidental chlorine releases and will respond to emergency releases only to assess and take defensive measures.  Skinner Plant also includes employees trained in the Incident Command System, who can coordinate with and provide technical assistance to outside emergency responders.  Depending on the severity of the accidental release, external hazardous materials response agencies, such as the Riverside County Fire Department, will be called to handle a chlorine release.  Skinner Plant management coordinates with local response agencies (Riverside County Fire Department) to help ensure that they are familiar with the Skinner Plant Chlorine System and its emergency requirements and that it is reflected in their Area Plans.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Numerous changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were identified, evaluated and resolved for the chlorine process as a result of Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) conducted prior to implementation of the new Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility, a significant additional safety enhancement and risk reduction measure. Further changes were identified in June 2006 and September 2007, when the process hazard and seismic risk analyses were updated to include the new chlorine containment and scrubbing system modification.  Additional recommendations were developed as part of the Five-Year Update PHA and Seismic Assessments, in 2011 and 2012, respectively.

gement of Change Procedure, HSE 108.5, describes the process that must be completed prior to implementing changes to the chlorine system. The Management of Change process of Metropolitan provides a system and approach to maintain and implement any management of change or modifications to equipment, procedures, chemicals, and processing conditions.  This system allows Skinner Plant employees to identify and review safety hazards or provide additional safety, process, or chemical information to existing data before the proposed change would either compromise system safety or need training to be completed.

Internal Compliance Audits

Internal compliance audits are conducted every three years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in the RMP.  Metropolitan management assembles an audit team that includes personnel knowledgeable in the Risk Management Program rule and in the process.  This team evaluates whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of the Risk Management Program rule and whether the prevention program is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the process.  The results of the audit are documented, and a plan is developed to resolve the recommendations and implement appropriate enhancements to the prevention program.  The last internal compliance audit was completed in May 2023. 

Incident Investigation

Skinner Plant management investigates all incidents that resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release (serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment) so that similar accidents can be prevented.  If required, an investigation team is assembled, and the investigation is initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process enhancements are implemented.  Information found during the investigation is reviewed by affected staff and added or used to revise operating and maintenance proce

Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program

Skinner Plant management ensures that a Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) is completed for any new process covered by this regulation, or for significant modifications to an existing covered process that requires a change in the process safety information.  

Skinner Plant management maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment.  The Skinner Plant mechanical integrity program includes the following:

- Written procedures for maintaining mechanical integrity through inspection and testing of process equipment, based on instructions of equipment manufacturers, industry codes and practice, and prior operating experience.
- Implementation of the written procedures by performing inspections and tests on process equipment at specified intervals.
- Training of maintenance personnel in preventive maintenance program procedures; safe work practices such as lockout/tagout, line or equipment opening, and avoidance and correction of unsafe conditions; and safe use and application of special equipment or unique tools.

Hot Work Permits and Management of Change 

Skinner Plant management requires employees and contractors to employ safe work practices when performing “hot work” in, on, or around the covered process.  Skinner Plant management uses a permitting and training program to ensure hot work is monitored and conducted safely on or near a process involving chlorine.

Operating Procedures

Skinner Plant management maintains up-to-date, accurate, written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for the chlorine process.  The Skinner Plant ensures effective operating practices by combining them with operating and maintenance training programs.  Standard operating procedures (SOPs) provide system descriptions, specifications, equipment inspection requirements, and operating procedures for the chlorine system.  The operating procedures include connection and disconnection for chlorine storage vessels, start-up and shutdown for chlorine evaporators, after maintenance start-up for chlorine evaporators, maintenance shutdown for chlorine evaporators, start-up and shutdown for ejectors, start-up and shutdown for chlorinators, chlorine system emergency shutdown, start-up following an emergency shutdown, and temporary operations.  Also included are the maintenance and troubleshooting procedures, including consequences of deviation and the steps to correct or avoid deviations.  Skinner Plant management reviews procedures annually and updates them if necessary or whenever a change occurs that alters the steps needed to operate safely. Chemical-specific prevention steps include a chlorine containment and scrubbing system to capture and neutralize an accidental chlorine release, availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine supply, awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine, presence of chlorine detectors and alarms, and a remotely controlled shutoff device on the chlorine storage vessel that can be activated automatically or by remote control.

Process and Chemical Safety Information

Comprehensive chemical data have been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine.  This information includes chlorine background information and Safety Data Sheets (SDS).

Equipment safety information is meticulously compiled on the chlorine process. Specifications for chlorine process are collected and provided in one place for easy reference. Details such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; safe upper and lower pressures; and codes and standards used to design, build, and operate the processes are on file at the facility.  Metropolitan also has procedures in place that are triggered to update process safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.

The chlorine pressure reducing valves, leak detectors, and computer control system are connected to the uninterruptible power supply (UPS) system.  In the event power is lost at the Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility, an alarm will alert the control room.  The water treatment plant has an emergency generator system, which provides backup power to run the plant, including the Chlorine System and scrubber units, in the event of a power failure.

The control room at the plant is manned 24 hours a day, year-round.  Access to the plant is through guarded security gates, which are closed after regular hours when the plant is patrolled by security guards.  The Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility is monitored by video cameras from the control room and has door alarms.

Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The Skinner Plant complies with Federal and State Process Safety Management requirements.  The Skinner Plant accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:
- Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.
- Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.
- Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.
- Performance of process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.
- Use of state-of-the-art process and safety equipment.
- Use of accurate and effective operating and maintenance procedures, written, reviewed, and certified annually with the participation of the operators, plant specialists, mechanics, managers, PSM/RMP compliance staff and technical writers.
- High level of training of the operators and maintenance staff, plus job-based, tailored training and plant oversight/escorts for

The ejectors are located at various points throughout the facility and introduce chlorine (under vacuum) into service water to form chlorine solution that subsequently mixes with the water supply at different stages of the treatment process for disinfection purposes.

The Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility (CCHF) is continuously monitored in the control room by video cameras, process condition transmitters (pressure, flow, etc.) and chlorine leak detectors. Chlorine leak detectors are provided in the storage bays, evaporator rooms, chlorinator room, pipe tunnels and ejector cabinets.  Based on the concentration and location of chlorine detected, the leak detection system will activate a succession of safety measures, beginning with visual and audible alarms, the start-up of the chlorine neutralization system and shut down of the normal ventilation system, and finally, automatically closing the storage vessel liquid chlorine angle valve.  The alarms are annunciated at the chlorine alarm panel as well as at the operator’s console in the control room.  Once alerted, fully trained personnel will respond to assess the chlorine leak.  In addition, each storage vessel valve connecting to the process is provided with a remotely actuated (pneumatic) emergency shutoff system.  In case of a major chlorine leak, chlorine supply can be stopped almost instantaneously by closing the shutoff system, automatically or manually from any of three control panels: unloading platform, chlorine maintenance room, or control room.  Emergency showers and eyewash stations are also provided throughout the Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility including the scrubber system.

ast of the I-15 and 215-freeway junction.  The facility was constructed in 1976 and covers 345 acres adjacent to Lake Skinner.  The plant is designed to treat drinking water, including disinfection with chlorine.  The facility currently stores and uses chlorine, a regulated toxic substance under the RMPR and CalARP Program rules, as well as the Federal and California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standards.

The Chlorine System at the Skinner Plant is composed of the following components: (1) a totally contained chlorine feed system to receive, store, and deliver liquid chlorine to the evaporators, chlorine expansion vessels, associated piping and valving, leak sensors and monitors, and instrumentation, (2) totally contained evaporators to convert the chlorine to gas for use in the chlorinators (evaporator units, associated piping and valving, instrumentation and vent exhaust gas arrestors (VEGA units), (3) totally contained chlorinators to regulate flow of chlorine gas under vacuum to the ejectors (chlorinator units, associated piping and valving, instrumentation), (4) ejectors to mix the chlorine gas with service water and inject chlorine solution at application points throughout the plant, and (5) chlorine gas treatment systems for capture and neutralization of an accidental chlorine release in the contained areas (scrubbers, caustic soda, fans, pumps, and associated piping and valving).

The chlorine storage vessels are totally contained in the Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility storage bays.

The process flow for the Chlorine System begins at the liquid chlorine angle valves located on the storage vessels in each storage bay, connected by flexible metallic hose to the fixed piping system.  Liquid chlorine is transferred by its own vapor pressure from an on-line storage vessel in each storage bay to one or more evaporators in each evaporator room.

The CCHF, which is equipped with two chlorine vapor scrubbing systems, was made to further enhance safety and mitigate offsite consequences of an accidental chlorine release.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Metropolitan’s accidental release prevention policy for chlorine involves a unified approach that integrates proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices.  All applicable procedures of the State of California and EPA's RMP Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response.  The Skinner Plant has a good safety record of chlorine use.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California (Metropolitan) treats and distributes drinking water to member water agencies throughout Southern California.  Metropolitan provides approximately 40 percent of the drinking water used by nearly 19 million people living on the southern California coastal plain between Ventura County and the Mexican border and is one of the largest distributors of treated drinking water in the United States, delivering an average of 1.5 billion gallons of water per day to a 5,200-square-mile service area.

Disinfection is a critical process used by Metropolitan in the treatment of its drinking water.  Disinfection helps to protect public health by killing pathogens in the water and preventing the spread of waterborne diseases.  The use of chlorine as a disinfectant in the treatment of drinking water and wastewater has been the dominant disinfection method in the United States since it was introduced, around the beginning of the last century.  Metropolitan currently utilizes bulk chlorine for disinfection at all of its water treatment plants, including the Robert A. Skinner Water Treatment Plant (Skinner Plant).

As one might expect from its superior disinfection properties, chlorine is a hazardous substance.  Thus, storing and handling chlorine can present a risk to employees and the public without proper precautions.  Metropolitan regards safe practices in the storing and usage of chlorine to be of primary importance and has an excellent safety record with chlorine.  To further safe practices, Metropolitan constructed a Chlorine Containment and Handling Facility in 2008 to contain all chlorine inside a building which is protected by vapor scrubbers.
